physDesc.p: This letter is five pages long. The word Aldington is written in pencil in the top left at a forty-five- degree angle slanting upwards from left to right. The date is in the top right of all pages and the annotation “R.A.--[Page #]” is in the top left of all pages after the first.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: This will be a very short letter, as I have not much to report. I enclose a money-order for the five dollars which was paid you by “The Dial” for the Henri de Régnier article. As I wrote to Hilda the other day, I shall have to be a little patient about collecting from “The Poetry Review” for your two poems that appeared in that, as they are always slow about paying, but I think I shall have it in a week or two, as they always do pay in the end.

Harriet writes me that she will take I and IV of your “Spring Moods,” “Beauty Unpraised” and “Ave.” She tells me that she is writing this to you direct. She has not returned the other manuscripts to me, which makes me rather angry, as I was going to try “The Seven Arts” with them. I am afraid she has sent them to you.

I think we are looking up, as I have been rather lucky in placing these things of yours, and I sold a poem of Fletcher’s to “The Century” the other day. Of the things you sent me I have sold “Images” and “Inarticulate Grief” as well as your “Mallarme” to “The Poetry Review.” I have sold your “Henri de Régnier” to “The Dial,” as you see. And I have sold these other two to “Poetry.” I do not believe that I can get rid of the Louys article anywhere, as on account of his erotic quality people over here do not want to read about him. I will make a stab at “The Seven Arts” with it, but I do not think there is much hope.

They paid very little for the Henri de Régnier article, as you see. “The Dial” has just changed hands, as I wrote you the other day, and they are not paying very high rates; but it has a very large circulation, and this is the first time that any of our group has been represented in it in any way – they have been our bitterest enemies hitherto – and I thought it better to accept a small price for the sake of the publicity; and I trust you will think I did right.

Things are going very well here. I am sending you a copy of a paper called “The National,” which contains an article about all of us, and especially about me, simply because I happen to be here; also a copy of “The Independent,” which featured me this week; and as I say, the fact that I have had so little difficulty in selling these things that you and Fletcher sent, makes me feel that we are all coming on very well. I think whatever you can send me that refers to the war, I shall have no difficulty in placing. If you happen to write a poem, or anything you have experienced while in camp, send it right along. I think I can put it somewhere with the greatest ease.

I had a letter from Hilda the other day telling me of Lawrence’s distressed condition. It came too late for me to take her advice about augmenting the amount of his royalties. As a matter of fact, I should not have done that anyway, for I do not like deception, and it would have angered me to have it practiced up on me. But I will send him some money, with a note, which I trust will enable him to accept it without scruple. Tell Hilda I will write to her very soon.

Where is your photograph in uniform? As I wrote you, I am sure I can get it into “The Transcript,” and I wish you would send it along. Also ask Hilda to send me another one of her, as I do not want to do anything to injure this one I have, and I will have it put in a review of her book, which Houghton Mifflin are bringing out in the Autumn. I think I can get Braithwaite to write a special article reviewing that book, and using the picture, without much difficulty. All these things help not only the person of whom they especially treat, but they help us all, and we want to keep the ball rolling – rolling right through the war and out the other side – so that we shall be in a splendid position to realize the new interest in things other than military, when the war is over.

I think that, as you are all on the other side except me, now, you had better all arrange between you the things you think best for the Anthology, and then send them over to me. They ought to reach me not later than the first of December, if possible. Then I will use my prerogative of objecting or accepting, as we all do, if it seems to be necessary to have any separate opinion over these, which I doubt; but as there is only me over here to decide, it will be much easier for you to get together there, so that I do not have to ask the various factions of you whether you approve before putting them into the book. It takes such an everlasting time for mail to go back and forth across the ocean nowadays, that I would rather deal directly with Hilda, and let her do all the collecting of the material, and not have to write specifically to each individual member. The book has to go to press, as you know, in February.

I am doubtful about putting a preface at all in this number. It seems to me to we have prefaced enough, and it would perhaps seem more dignified, and look as if we were more certain of our position in this last one of our Anthologies (for you remember our contract was only for three years), if we appear without any apology or explanation of any sort. I think the Anthology has done its work: we have made a good position for ourselves, we are taken seriously, and I think we have done that almost impossible thing – come very near to changing the whole taste for poetry, certainly in this country. There are a number of conservative poets still writing, and a few people who like them, but they have nothing like the vogue they had, and the interest is all turning our way, I think simply because we are so absolutely sincere and have believed so absolutely in the things we have tried to embody in our work; and to my mind it is one of the most hopeful things about the whole movement that the sincerity which is in us has sprung an answering echo in the interest which we have been accorded. I had the following instance in the mail the other day. Evidently someone had compared Sandburg’s and George Sterling’s poems, unfavourably to the former. Sandburg writes me as follows:
“Dear Miss Lowell:
I am sending copies of this to my publishers, Louis Untermeyer and yourself so you may know our supposed enemy critics do not always have the backing of our supposed enemy poets.
Carl Sandburg”
The copy was as follows:
Dear Mr. Sandburg:

I have just seen the unfortunate reference to our poems in “Current Opinion,” and lest you imagine that I like that sort of thing, I write to say how deeply I deplore it, and how sincerely I am the admirer of the splendid vitality and imagination of your work.

In the light of the new movement in poetry, I feel something of a Rip Van Winkle, which feeling, I fear, detracts a good deal from the compliment when I assure you that I would gladly change places with you in the literary (if I may call it that) world. I am not your imitator merely because this old dog can be taught new tricks, but somehow has no heart for them.
Long life to you and the success that you deserve!
George Sterling”

Of course, Sandburg is not one of our group, but he is doing a species of poetry which is quite unlike the old-fashioned kind, and I for one am an admirer of his effort and often of his achievement, though not always. I think he is one of the best things we have over here, and that a man like Sterling, whose stuff is so fearfully old-fashioned and who has an enormous clientèle on the Pacific Coast, should write so generous a letter is, I think, an excellent sign.

Never forget when you are sitting in the trenches or doing anything else in regard to your present job, that you have done an immense amount to change the whole attitude of poetry, and that nothing can ever take that away from you, no matter what you may be doing at the moment.
Send me that photograph! And with lots of love, Dear Boy, to you and Hilda, from both Mrs. Russell and me,
